I watched Made in Abyss having not really heard much of the hype. I watched the first three episodes and found them to be thoroughly enjoyable, with the beginnings of some intriguing world-building and well fleshed-out characters. Shortly after watching these first three episodes I headed off on a trip to Tasmania and was soon enough distracted by travel and didn't think a great deal more of it. However, courtesy of the chap sitting next to me on the flight down I soon found-myself bed-ridden and staying in Tasmania a little longer than planned. With nothing much to do, my thoughts turned back to Madein Abyss and before I knew it I'd binged the remaining ten episodes and was left being still very much sick and now also bereft that there wasn't more. I had this palpable, intense urge to watch more, to explore the deeper layers, just as the characters in the show do. It's been a long time since any story in any medium left me quite so profoundly impacted. I promptly devoured the manga.


The show constructs the Abyss and its lore with incredible attention to detail. It builds ecosystems, history, layered mystery and the geography of the place. And whilst the Abyss is clearly said to be dangerous, it doesn't take long before you start seeing just how very, truly, painfully true that is. 


Perhaps one of the finest points of this world is the White Whistles. They are not your standard generic hero-adventurers. Without revealing too much, as we meet them we realise just what the Abyss does to people who spend their lives in it and just what sort of person devotes themselves so totally to this realm of beautiful nightmares. It is through what we see of them that we get a sense of the deep mystery and deep horror of the Abyss. 


The show is a descent in every sense of the world. The bright, if not exactly utopian city of Orth, is populated by moe red whistle children and those first three episodes build the foundations of a fun and exciting adventure. From there all illusions we may have had about what sort of story this will be a stripped away, layer by layer, with ruthless care. For all my praise of this show, parts of it are genuinely painful to watch. There are certainly more graphically violent anime out there, but none make you suffer with the characters, make you experience their pain and deprivation, quite like Made in Abyss. 


For a show with adventure at its core to truly succeed there needs to be mystery, a sense of journeying into the unknown and few works I've experience build that sense more effectively than Made in Abyss. The names of places, relics and people give you some sense of this: the Sea of Corpses, the Capital of the Unreturned, the Final Maelstrom are three of the layers of the Abyss mentioned early on, but left mostly unexplained, giving our imaginations space to run wild. We have the Unheard Bell and the Curse-Repelling Vessel... then there's the White Whistles and their epithets - Ozen the Immovable, Bondrewd the Novel, Lord of Dawn... it is evocative stuff. And that's how this show builds mystery - it gives you tantalising glimpses and lets you construct the rest. 


I'd be remiss in reviewing this series and not mentioning its soundtrack. Kevin Penkin has provided a true masterpiece here. From the enigmatic, intriguing 'The First Layer' which plays at numerous times early in the series and effectively invokes the sense of mystery and adventure mentioned above, to the stirring 'Tomorrow' and the truly mind-blowing 'Hanezeve Caradhina', this soundtrack is quite unlike anything I've ever experienced and perfectly accompanies this wonderful series' Ghibli-esque visuals. 


You will want to join Reg and Riko on this journey. It is unique. It is at times cruel, at times beautiful, at times uplifting and at times devastatingly depressing.  It is one of those series that sticks with you, almost haunting you after you're done.

I'll be honest, when I first started watching this show I was not instantly drawn in, I thought it was a bit weird, a bit slow, I got a little bored, however it ended up being my favourite anime of all time.
The animation is great with some breathtaking visuals and awesome voice work and a truly outstanding OST. The story is extremely intriguing and has so many directions it can go in that you cant help but be excited for what will happen next.
The concept of the show, the mysterious abyss and the consequences of the curse, pull you in and make you want toexplore it alongside the main characters and see what the abyss has to offer too. There are a lot of funny sweet moments and it pulls you in with a child's curiosity, slowly turning into a dark corner. There are many moments that are beautiful and make you want to cry and a lot of moments that give you goosebumps and makes your jaw drop.


There are a range of characters with all kinds of quirky personalities but id say most of them are very charming and likeable in their own ways, as everyone is working individually and together to discover the mysteries hidden with-in the abyss. As scary and weird as some of the characters can be, you can come to understand it somewhat due to the concept of their world.


Compared to the manga, there is not much to be missed from this segment of the show apart from some fighting visualisation and more blunt nudity and such. However the anime has some extra parts in it that the manga does not that give the story a bit of an extra kick and shows off more of the amazing features of the story. The colour and amazing OST also does the manga a great service.


Overall this anime is a breathtaking experience and leaves you wanting more, makes you emotional and has a lot of chilling moments. If you are into plot twists, dark themes, emotional stories and a world full of mystery, you will love this show! If you are looking for a cute and innocent story about children exploring the unique world, you might be in for a shock though, so be wary of that.


A lovely show and a breath of fresh air for me, I highly recommend it!

I'm not very used to writing reviews yet, so I'll probably be hesitant and undecided, but I had to make one on Made in Abyss. And what a way to start!
Story :  10/10
I could only give 10, because Made in Abyss touches a sore spot at home by playing the card of discovery, adventure and mystery. Indeed, I have always loved discovering new things, especially totally different worlds, which I find extremely attractive.
And there, at once, I am offered a beautiful but deadly place, a mysterious and unknown fauna and flora, a sensation of attraction for the unknown, a dangerous but exquisite perfume oftemptation...

I do not really have words to describe everything, but I know that I have the impression to discover the world of Made in Abyss at the same time as Riko and Regu, I am amazed at each new discovery, with each new advance . I am fascinated by the Abyss, as much as Riko could be!

I have only one hurry : a second season to quench my thirst for exploration!


Art : 10/10

My eyes ! It's so beautiful !

Let's start with the "less impressive": the chibi aspect of the characters can be confusing at the beginning, but we get used to it very quickly and, finally, it sticks strangely with the general universe of the anime

The animation of the characters is impeccable and the monsters animation is really interesting, in a quite different style but not a displeasing one.

But the strong point of the DA is the sets : they are simply sumptuous. It's like being in a Ghibli! The universe of the Abyss is incredibly detailed and magnified (which contrasts with its true nature). The different levels are diversified and we really feel like there's different ecosystems

It's impressive to see how much this anime can score in just so few episodes!


Sound : 10/10

Made in Abyss was a surprise and my favorite 2017 anime, thanks to its rich and detailed universe, its artistic direction but also its soundtrack!

Music plays a vital role in a work. It accompanies the characters, rhythm an episode and occupies an essential place in the construction of the atmosphere.

As much to say it immediately: it reaches perfection in Made in Abyss.

The OST is beautiful, splendid, sublime. Sometimes we have majestic orchestral pieces (usually accompanied by breathtaking panoramas), sometimes they are rather discrete music, sticking perfectly to the atmosphere of the Abyss.

Hanezeve Caradhina, played from the first episode, plunges us into this wonderful universe

The First Layer plunges us at the same time as the characters in the discovery of the Abyss. We begin an enigmatic, initiatic, journey, which we know we will not come back unscathed

In the Blind translates the dark, oppressive side of the Abyss. The danger, omnipresent, invisible, awaits us, and despite the beauty and majesty of the place, the slightest misstep can be fatal

Finally, Tomorrow concludes with unparalleled strength our first part of the journey, alongside Riko, Regu and Nanachi


Of all the anime OSTs that I have heard, Made in Abyss is by far the one that struck me the most

I would also like to share a theory, or rather a personal interpretation, which for me has also played a great role: in a number of tracks of the OST, a particular kind of instrument comes up quite frequently. A low-pitched, resonant, vibrating instrument.

For me, this instrument is the representation of the Abyss. Mysterious, haunting, scary, it is a deep emptiness, omnipresent, that attracts us constantly throughout the anime. This omnipresence, this fascination is so powerful that we even feel it through music.


Characters: 10/10

"Oh, chibi characters, this anime is going to be adorable" - Me, before episode 10

Once we get used to the particular chara design (which sticks surprisingly well with the world of Made in Abyss), we can only appreciate the characters of this anime

Complex, surrounded by mystery, trailing behind them a past, the characters are directly influenced by the Abyss.

If we can notice some characters are a little too manichean (Bondrewd I see you coming), we can only be amazed at the complexity of the characters.

The children of the orphanage are adorable, but are at the same time aware of the dangers of life since they already rub shoulders with exploring the Abyss, even if this is only the first layer. Inchou perfectly plays the role of an orphanage director as we learned in storytelling, which makes her a surprisingly pleasant character.

Whistles are people who saw things,  they're even tortured. They saw the Abyss, its dark side. They escaped, but as soon as they set foot there, if only once, the Abyss took a part of their soul, pushing them to always want to return.

So what about Ouzen, the unshakable giant, a fascinating and really well written character! Mentor, she differs very much from the classical scheme instituted by the animes, but is nevertheless an unequaled teacher.

And what about Nanachi and Mitty! A tragic story, heartbreaking and deeply human, which results in a magnificent but terribly painful act.


And of course, let's not forget Riko and Regu, our two protagonists!

Regu, half-human half-robot boy, who goes back to the bottom of the Abyss to understand who he is, what his origins are but also to accompany Riko on her journey

And Riko, ah Riko! What a great character!

If her enthusiasm, her little face and her desire to find her mother are touching, it is especially her maturity and knowledge that have struck me.

It is difficult to find in an anime a character who really thinks and uses his knowledge with accuracy. Yet here is a 12-year-old girl doing it.

And if, of course, she makes mistakes and encounters "setbacks", it is extremely pleasant to see how well she has prepared herself and knows how to deal with the world outside (doesn't it, Priestess of Goblin Slayer? )


Enjoyment : 10/10

I did not get bored for a minute. I enjoyed every shot, every line of dialogue, every character. The really unique atmosphere of the anime really struck me, I was captivated with each episode (that's why I finished the anime really fast!)


Overall : 10/10

I think that today, I still do not have words strong enough to describe what I went through with Made in Abyss. It was really ... wonderful. Every detail of this anime hit me, touched me in the heart and fascinated me

I have always had an attraction for discovery, exploration, as much as saying that this anime delight me completely!

Despite its length, Made in Abyss has directly managed to be among my favorite anime, a top 10 well deserved in my opinion

Although it is recent, I think it has already become a classic to see absolutely once in our life


Now, we only have wait impatiently for the second season!

Made in Abyss is an anime beautifully crafted by studio Kinema Citrus. It features characters with their own little unique twists, art in which every frame can be used as a background for your computer, soundtracks that you'd carry with you just to listen, and memorable characters.
Kinema Citrus isn't very popular, understandably - after all, they made some mediocre anime that normally features a 7/10; examples being: 
- Black Bullet (2014)
- Yuyushiki (2013)
- Gochiusa (2015)
They don't typically do a lot of action anime, and more inclined to and successful with the slice of life genre, and to anyone who bears witness to Kinema Citrus, prepareto be shocked: they delivered a masterpiece.


Story (9/10): The story is revolved around Riko, a young girl who is a Red Whistle, an apprentice Cave Raider - the most inexperienced of Cave Raiders - and Riko wishes to and aspires to be a White Whistle just like her legendary, famous mother, Lyza. The Cave Raiders constantly go in and out of the Abyss, a huge pit that dwells far into the Earth, holding relics and unique, and simultaneously deadly creatures.

This concept expresses that of a huge imagination and I felt that the studio did everything right in their power in expressing the story as beautifully as they can. You can understand most concepts, and you might get lost a few times, but you'll have painted the general picture and perhaps hold an attachment to the creative ideas given to you.


Art (10/10): You can tell that most of it appears to be frame-by-frame instead of CG. Generally-speaking, frame-by-frame hand-drawn is better, but there are definitely a few moments where there is CG - and Kinema Citrus managed to make it blend well with the traditional art style. There's barely anything that looks out of place, and the animators sure deserve a commendation for the hard work they put into every detail. There are so many moments that you could just screencap and use as a background for your computer.


Sound (9/10): An amazing, exhilarating soundtrack. There are two soundtracks that you'll fall in love with, those being:

Hanezeve Caradhina (ft.Takeshi Saito)

Underground River (ft.Raj Ramayya)

The soundtrack is incredibly unique and definitely fits the fantasy feel that you get from watching this anime. Whoever was in charge of sound effects was definitely trying to put as many sounds appropriate to try and attach the viewers to what they were viewing, and it worked generally well. Every single clink, every single tap, every single footstep and contact, you could hear and feel.


Character (8/10): The two main characters, Reg and Riko have their own quirks about them, and even then, the characters that surround them and are of less importance have their own special quirks about them. You'll come to appreciate each character you come across, even if they don't have quite a lot of screentime. Unique, every single one of them. However, it is due to this uniqueness that sometimes, there is too much emphasis on a character and you'll be expecting so much more from them, but they are definitely in-depth.


Enjoyment (10/10): The episodes just engage you, and with each episode, you just yearn for the next. There are short clips of the last moments of previous episodes at the start of each, so you'll be able to get the gist of what happened last time, and keep pushing on. It's so engaging, and all of the elements presented tie into that. You could feel as if you were there.


Overall, 10/10. Congrats, Kinema Orange - I just hope you can keep up this much quality into what you cover.

(Tried my best to avoid anything major, and phrased things to be less direct, stop reading after the first paragraph if you want to play it real safe)
Alright, some basic things out of the way, first thing, this will by no means be a unbiased review, hell, no review should be, all opinion and so on. Second thing, this won’t be very structured, additionally it’ll very casually written, and mostly a lot of gushing, simply so I can explain why I enjoyed this show so much. I’m not going to recap the story, but I’ll also avoid directspoilers as much as possible, you don’t need to have watched the show, but some things in this review won’t make sense. One last thing, I won't be doing that stupid Art / Sound / Story / Entertainment / Overall Format, it boils everything down to the technical aspects,and poorly at that. Alright, let’s dive in.


Alright, before anything, I think it's safe to assume this we can agree show excels in all technical aspects. Those sweet Ghibli backgrounds, the music and sound design, fight choreography is on point, and hits feel impactful. The world building is fantastic, but everyone has already praised that, and if you've seen the show you know all this already. The stuff that really got me into the show, on top of the just well done execution, is everything else. First of all, I'm a character guy through and through, I love getting invested in multi-faceted characters that grow over the course of the narrative. Made in Abyss has me covered in spades on this front, as a large part of the show is focused on the interactions with each other, and the world, not to mention the growth or our two main characters, Riko and Regu. Riko and Regu are able to perfectly play off of each, Regu has the physical capabilities, while Riko has the intuition and resolve Regu lacks. Moreover, Riko is more passionate, while Regu is more sensical, and both are able to bring these traits to each other. While most of the season is focused on Riko, and her growth as a character, following Nanachi’s introduction Regu is given plenty more room to grow. The character design is also top notch, with every major character being unique with a distinct silhouette. Characters aside, I love the setting of Made in Abyss, the entire aesthetic, which is hard to put a label on, and the Abyss itself. Given the very nature of the Abyss it lends itself to a variety of different environments which are both visually appealing, and provides new adversities for the characters to face. The soundtrack of the show also perfectly encapsulates the adventurous nature of the show.


The second topic I’d like to cover is the themes behind the show, which is to saying the meaning or message. This part is going to be really unorganized, as it's hard to explain what I mean by any of this without rambling. The central theme of Made in Abyss, is simply the strength of passion and commitment, even if is foolish and entirely illogical. Their longing for the bottom of the abyss it foolish, they aren’t prepared, and any reason should persuade them otherwise, but it's human, the journey is driven by nothing but pure emotion. Ozen is the first major roadblock where this is brought into question. Everything she says during the brawl is logical and reasonable, they shouldn’t continue their journey, everything is vien, but this stance lacks any humanity or emotion, and this is revealed following the fight as Ozen doesn’t really believe in anything she said. Nanachi on the other hand, had her driving force unjustly ripped from her and resigned to like of passivity, Regu, is both able to physically, and emotionally deal with the weights holding Nanachi down. I’ve already mentioned how the soundtrack works perfectly, but more specifically the OP. The lyrics alone cover everything I’ve already mentioned, and how any challenges they face only furthers that drive. There's one part in particular I’d like to focus on, around 2:15 - 2:55. At the end of the verse Miyu’s (Riko’s) voice drops off and the entire song slows down and becomes more somber, both lyrically and instrumental wise. Additionally, there are larger gaps of time between the two different vocalists.Nearing the end of this section, Riko’s voice becomes more uplifting before both voices join back in unison with beat picking back and the lyrics also become more positive, if not more mature and aware now.


All in all, I’m don’t expect anyone to agree with everything, if anything, I said here. I simply put this down on paper as a way of explaining why I enjoyed this series so much, fingers crossed for a season two, and if I’m reading the manga. Thanks for taking time to read this absolute mess of a review.

Made in Abyss is one of the best anime which have come out in 2017. The anime creates a very unique experience through an amazing soundtrack, amazing animation and a mysterious adventure through a giant chasm known as the Abyss, where many strange creatures live in all kinds of mysterious landscapes like forests which are upside down.
Story: 8/10
The story of Made in Abyss starts in a town called ‘Orth’ which is built around the giant chasm known as the Abyss. Many explorers live in this town, trying to discover the mysteries of the Abyss and find the many treasures known as relics. However, the Abyssis a very dangerous place with all kinds of hostile monsters and a curse which activates when people try to leave the Abyss. The curse can cause all kinds of symptoms, with the symptoms becoming worse with every floor lower the explorers try to leave the Abyss from. Thus far only 6 floors have been discovered, with the bottom of the Abyss still not being found. Because of the dangers of the Abyss explorers need to prove their skills, which is marked by whistles with a red whistle being the lowest level, only allowed to go to the first floor and the white whistles being the highest level, being allowed to explore as far as they want. The world building of Made in Abyss sets up for a great adventure with many new places being discovered and mysteries being solved. Questions like how the Abyss was created, why it is the way it is, how far down the Abyss goes or why the curse of the Abyss exists are recurring throughout the series. For example, human skeletons who are praying towards the middle of the Abyss seem to be found in several different places, which could have to do with an event causing the creation of the Abyss. The anime also deals with themes like existentialism with the robot-like boy Regu who does not know where he came from or what he really is. Unfortunately, the story leaves many questions open in the first season and many events are still left unknown because of that. However, the story is very good overall. 


Art and animation: 9/10

Made in Abyss has a very unique art style, using a chibi like art style for the characters. Its character designs are overall very unique and fit the many different characters well. The anime also makes use of beautiful animation, animating the many unique landscapes of the Abyss in a very detailed manner, with its beautiful animation also seen in scenes like in the first episode, when the sun rises and shines over the city of Orth. The only real downside to the animation is the somewhat bad CGI used for some of the monsters in the fight scenes. However, the show looks very beautiful overall and is definitely worth watching if you want to see many beautifully animated landscapes. 


Sound:  10/10

To really create a very fitting atmosphere for the many different places in the world of Made in Abyss, the anime uses a variety of different soundtracks to really set the mood for the anime. These songs can give a real sense of a mysterious adventure through an unknown world. Even standing above the rest of the amazing soundtrack is the main theme ‘Hanezeve Caradhina’ used in several episodes of the anime. The voice actors also do an amazing job performing the voices for all the different characters. Through the voice actors, the different emotions the characters have during different moments really get conveyed well. Though the quality of music can differ from person to person, I would definitely recommend listening to some of the music of Made in Abyss, because of its outstanding soundtrack. 


Characters: 8/10

The characters can be an interesting point to argue about in Made in Abyss. I would say that some of the side characters are even more interesting and better developed than the main characters. This is because the main characters, at the beginning of the anime, have a simple personality with a few different character traits, but many things unknown about their origins. Riko is the daughter of the white whistle Lyza and has apparently been born on the fourth floor of the Abyss, with many mysteries surrounding her birth. Regu is a robot-like boy who has unconsciously saved Riko from a monster on the first floor. He does not remember anything about himself, but it seems as he has been created or born somewhere in the Abyss. Riko is very energetic and pretty stubborn, being able to think pretty rationally during fights against monsters. Regu is a pretty strong fighter, although he is pretty shy and often unable to make quick decisions in fights. Through their different personalities the two main characters do make a good team. There are also some very interesting side characters, like Ouzen and Nanachi. Ouzen is a white flute who seems to have a very sinister character, who seems to have had a bit of a character change through living on the second floor of the Abyss for a long time. However, she also seems to have a good side to her character, willing to help the protagonists in their journey. Her backstory explains the way she acts to the characters for the most part, which is also true for Nanachi. Overall the characters are very good but leave a lot of room for improvement. 


Enjoyment: 9/10

Overall, this was a very enjoyable anime for me. The anime has got pretty interesting characters, world building which makes you curious to learn more about the Abyss and it uses great animation and an amazing soundtrack to really get you involved in the atmosphere of the show and take you on the adventure the main characters are having. Some episodes did feel a bit slower though and it probably would add to my enjoyment if the characters would be developed somewhat better throughout the anime. However, it is a very enjoyable anime to see unfold overall. 


Bonus Categories: 9/10

-----

Adventure: 9/10

Overall, Made in Abyss has created a very good atmosphere for the adventure it is having. There are a variety of unique landscapes being able to be explored with the animation and soundtrack really helping for the sense of adventure the anime gives off. You do not really know what to expect of the next landscapes to come on lower floors, with the floors beneath the sixth floor being totally unknown. There are also many relics to be found and there are a variety of different explorer classes, adding to the sense of adventure.


Mystery: 9/10

Many things in the anime are not (very well) known. The backgrounds of the main characters, the origin of the Abyss together with its depth and physics as well as the whereabouts of the mother of Riko. Only a few clues are given for some of the mysteries in this season, leaving a lot up to speculation. In the last few episodes of the anime even more mystery gets introduced, with the introduction of some new characters as well.

-----


Overall: 9/10 (8,83/10)

Made in Abyss is an amazing anime and one of the best ones which came out in 2017. Its combination of adventure, mystery, great sound and animation, as well as a good story and some interesting characters make for a great anime. It will be interesting to see where the anime goes in its sequel, as many questions are still unsolved and the main characters still have a lot of room for improvement.

Shinsekai Yori being my favorite anime of all time because of the unique dystopia setting , characters and godly worldbuilding I found the world in Made in Abyss fascinating and the whole reason that it caught my attention to watch this anime and  write a review for it. 
Since the first episode this anime managed to attract and introduce  its audience  to the characters , story and world. And things get better with each episode , it becomes an adventure told from the experiences and actions of our two main characters Riko&Reg.  Having a reason and purposeour two main characters venture into the Abyss to an unfamiliar world to them filled with dangerous beasts and consequences. It’s a journey to find more about  themselves for Riko&Reg who venture deeper and deeper into the unknown Abyss.

Everything is done right  starting with the waterfall shot at the end of episode 1  which has done its job to build up your interest for the next episode and the steady revealing of the mystery surrounding the Abyss done in each episode until the end leaving its audience amazed and with a thirst for more. Being an adventure a lot of dangers and obstacles await for our two main characters in each layer of the Abyss as they go deeper they discover the fascinating world and his inhabitants :The cave raiders, the legendary white whistles, the society created there , the dangerous beasts, the vegetation etc.

Each encounter Reg&Riko  have with the many inhabitants from the Abyss help them discover more about the mysteries surrounding the Abyss and about themselves. They grow stronger with each encounter and help each other to become stronger and fulfill their initial goal. FANTASTIC! .The title “Made in Abyss” is very suggestive for our two main characters and for their journey because it’s not about exploring the Abyss itself but to discover your own true self you must venture down into the dark abyss. I love the characters , they act natural in each situation they are curious and brave  have a mysterious past revolving on each of them and fit perfect in this adventure genre. Overall Made in Abyss is a great anime with gorgeous scenery, vivid and bright characters, with a fantastic worldbuilding , great ost , a story filled with adventure and a lot of morals  to learn from it that I enjoyed watching it.

Made in Abyss is a show that looks rather... typical on the surface. Cute child characters exploring various fantasy landscapes. But much like the abyss itself, there is far, far more to this show than meets the eye.
One of Made in Abyss' greatest strengths is certainly its visual direction. The world looks absolutely outstanding, with all kinds of locations that I've never seen anything even remotely similar to. This extends to the creatures that inhabit the abyss, too. Every episode is a delight when it comes to showing you new and interesting things. However, I did think during several points that the show was movingtoo fast for what it wanted us to see. There is indeed a second season on the horizon, but one or two more episodes in this season to slow down and let the world sink in would have been appreciated.


The story is also a particular strong point. The premise, like those of most great stories, is simple; Riko and her companion Reg want to travel to the bottom of "The Abyss". But as the plot advances, more layers of detail and intrigue are added on that make what initially seemed like a simple adventure into much more. Each of the characters in the show is a joy to watch and they share fantastic chemistry, which is due in no small part to the voice acting. Every member of the cast is giving it their all and it shows.


I'll cut to the chase. Should you watch Made in Abyss? Absolutely. You'll be enthralled by the gorgeous world and its inhabitants, and the story will pull you in hook, line and sinker, particularly in the latter half. I do wish it took its time more often, and there were some areas of the show that felt like they had far too much to show for the time that was allocated to them, but that's only a small gripe. Overall, this is truly a special show, and one you won't regret watching.

Made in Abyss grabbed my attention way back when it was first announced with it’s unique art on the teaser poster. However I didn’t get around to watch it for quite a while, I finished it about 30 minutes before writing this review actually.
So what are my thoughts on it? Let’s start the review.
- S T O R Y -
Despite the extremely thrilling premise that just yells ''GRANDIOSE ADVENTURE'', you really don't get any of that.
The characters barely go through anything yet progress so much due to the extremely fast pacing. The series is extremely telegraphed in that aspect, as you always know when Regand Riko face a big danger and manage to overcome it, they're practically at the end of the layer and will dive even further only for the same ''Explore a bit, get into a hopeless situation, prevail'' cycle to repeat.

 Practically the whole series' plot can be summed up to the same length of the previous paragraph.


The series does introduce a villain by the end of the season as a set up towards the announced sequel but he is nothing but a textbook bad guy, since nothing screams evil more than ''Booo gruesome experiments on children''.


Despite this, the series have a lot of emotion in them alongside an extremely well constructed world with a lot of potential for further development.


- C H A R A C T E R S -

Made in Abyss is full of visually distinct and memorable characters but a lot of them are extremely simple as personalities.

They have no depth or any inner conflicts, what you see is what you get. What the characters say, that's what they think, what they say, they feel, there's never a moment of subtlety or expressiveness without mentioning what they're expressing with words outside of a major moment in the final episode.

All of them have valid motives for what they're doing, be it sense of exploration accompanied with wanting to meet your mother who's waiting at the bottom of the Abyss or wanting to find out who you are. The motives don't feel weak but sometimes the conviction of the characters' does and unintentionally so.


- A R T  &  A N I M A T I O N -

The art is absolutely gorgeous, no other way around it. It's extremely detailed and atmospheric. The world couldn't have been portrayed better. The animation is good enough, although the quality jumps a lot.

It's usually above average with plenty of double framing and that works, but out of nowhere it can get real smooth and dynamic when an action scene comes. Which wouldn't have been so haphazard... if... the smooth animation didn't occasionally show up out of nowhere on some completely arbitrary moments. It's kind of evident whenever a better key animator's turn comes around to animate a portion of the episode.


That's a minor nitpick though. The smooth animation is welcome.

It compliments the show's world as a whole and could be really expressive given it's quality if the characters just let it do it's own work instead of yelling out their emotions constantly.


- S O U N D T R A C K -

The OST is fantastic, it's extremely memorable and almost always played at the right moment to play with your feelings. The whole track list has that sense of mystery, beauty, sadness and adventure at the same time so almost every piece of the score can be used at any given moment and it'd fit perfectly.

The compositions are mostly made of orchestral arrangements and medleys with touching vocals.

I do feel like the track ''Hanazeve Caradhina'' was played a bit too much (4 times in total) for what it was.

It's the most special track in the whole OST so it should've been handled with a bit more care as it's amazing.


- O V E R A L L -

I think Made in Abyss is a really good show overall with plenty of positives but is stopped from being the grandiose adventure it's supposed to be due to it's extremely quick pacing and lack of exploration. The characters sometimes feel like they literally fly past the Abyss' layers.

It's definitely worth a watch though. When Season 2 comes around I'll definitely watch it.

"Appearances can be deceiving" is the phrase That comes to mind when I think of Made in Abyss. Despite the characters chibi appearances there is a very mature story running through it. 
There is a giant hole aptly called the abyss that no one has ever seen the bottom of, and there is a community of cave raiders who have formed around it who delve its depth hoping to reach the base while also harvesting the treasures that lie in its bowels. The Abyss is no cakewalk though there are dangerous creatures that live in it and the landscape changes drastically the further one descends.Not to mention once one ascends they are stricken with the "curse of the abyss" which symptoms worsen the deeper one dives.


In order to try and drop the mortality rate, the community at the top of the abyss has developed a series of ranks denoted by whistles that tell you how far a person is allowed to descend with the status of the white whistle being the highest and having carte blanche on how far they can descend.  


In the upper layers near the surface is where we meet Riko, a red whistle which is basically a trainee cave delver.  While exploring Riko is saved by a mysterious robotic boy after being nearly killed by one of the abysses more dangerous creatures.  Riko takes the boy back to the orphanage she lives at as her mother one of the legendary white whistles has not been seen for years and is presumed dead. The robot boys name is Reg, and he has no memory of who he is but knows he comes from some of the lowest layers of the abyss. A letter from Riko mother arrives at the surface pretty much beckoning her to come to find her at the bottom of the abyss, and Riko heads off in search of her with Reg assisting Riko's descent with his capabilities. 


Some of the later episodes are rough emotionally, episode 10, in particular, I had trouble getting through a section because of the graphic nature, but I can't deny that it was handled well.


Made in Abyss is very well done, the people who made it clearly put the time and effort into making and adapting it that I could sing its praises all day. For me, it's, not something I absolutely love so that holds it from a 10 for me but, I can not deny that this is a fantastic show and have no issue recommending it.

After watching more than 500 anime, finding something unique and interesting especially with great execution is difficult. This show did it. 
Granted, I have a propensity for dark fantasy so take that as your basis for deciding whether to listen to what I say. What I CAN say with conviction is that if you liked Full Metal Alchemist:Brotherhood, this show has a similar feel: tech/fantasy mix, fascinating and unique world mechanics, beautiful art, but some harsh moments that can be hard to watch.
To some degree, my scores are a reflection of my immense relief to find something newfor a change, but I really think Made in Abyss stands up objectively. If I had to point to any single issue, it would be that the characters look 6 years old rather than 12, but it's an art style that I can overlook.\n\n
There's gratifyingly little fan service, enough that it doesn't seem like fan service at all (thank god... I'm so sick of crotches in my face). It has incredible powers, skill, capability, new worlds, new laws, new problems, and a wide and interesting cast. I don't know what else you could ask for. The only thing I'm left debating is whether to rate this as a solid 10 or not (sticking with 9 for now).

This show is astounding. It's about a girl named Riko who lives in an orphanage in a town beside a giant hole several hundred miles deep, full of mysterious artefacts of an ancient advanced civilisation, as well as giant monsters. One day she finds a robot boy whom she names Reg, and is given a message from her missing mother, saying that she is waiting for her at the bottom of the Abyss, prompting Riko and Reg to go on a quest to find her. However there's a curse on the Abyss that means the deeper you go, the greater the toll of traversing upwards,and it's made clear that the trip will only be one-way, as Riko will die if she tries to go back up from the seventh layer or below.

The series begins as a cute and fun drama, but the mounting dread and ever-present knowledge that the trip will be one-way for our young heroine makes every episode progressively more heartbreaking to watch, especially when Riko is as well written as she is (though she frustratingly never really develops as a character given the things she goes through).


The animation is astounding, far outclassing most KinemaCitrus anime, and the soundtrack, by Australian composer Kevin Penkin, contains some of the most beautiful pieces of music I have ever heard. The beauty and the horror of the situation are harmonised perfectly without any kind of tone-clash, and the story is so gripping that it's impossible not to want to keep wathcin. The rabbit girl Nanachi is also a remarkable character in terms of her motivation, backstory, and development. The tragedy is however that her introduction, appearing exactly when she needed to to save Riko after a horribly infected and poisoned arm almost kills her, makes her initially feel more like a plot-device than a character. Reg however embodies this totally. He initially has no motivation at all for helping Riko (only later developing a crush on her), and seems to only exist to keep saving her every time she should have died... if not for his elongated arms or death rays and whatever other powers he might have that are just what is needed at the time.


Despite Reg being walking plot-armour, the show frequently goes out of its way to torture Riko horribly, both physically and mentally, with the episode of her arm being poisoned and her bleeding out of her eyes, and ears while her hand swells to the width of her waist being extremely disturbing to watch, and the episode in which Ozen The Unmovable beats her and Reg up for no real reason, feeling like nothing more than torture porn. I get that the writer wanted it to be made clear how dangerous the situation is, but those incidents just felt like an excuse to torture Riko (and the audience) rather than progress the plot, which is really very slow in terms of describing what actually happens in the series. They are even more redundant when you consider that the giant monsters already show a sense of danger, and the sense of plot-armour that this would have involved could easily have been removed by including a character like Nat in their journey, then having that character killed by a monster part-way through. That way we would have understood the stakes of the situation without having to be put through what feels like hours of horrifying to watch brutal injuries.


It also feels like a huge shame that the archaeological aspect of the series's setting is never investigated; even the explorers of the Abyss are solely motivated by selling relics, rather than investigating them, and nothing is known about the Abyss's mythology or history. This seems both unrealistic (you'd have thought that the site would have been made a UNESCO World Heritage Site immediately after it was discovered) and feels like a waste of a good setting, since a lot of the mysteryies look unlikely to be solved in the near future. It also seems quite unrealistic that the orphanage Riko lives in forces children to go down exploring into the upper levels of the Abyss (where there are still monsters that occasionally show up to eat them). Surely this place should be shut down?...


There are also lots of awkward unfunny penis jokes in the series that ruin a lot of otherwise powerful scenes and are completely unnecessary.


The real problem with the series though is that it is almost entirely set-up for what is clearly a bugger story coming out in future seasons, but the good news is that Season 1 introduced so many mysteries and got me invested so much in the characters that I'm now absurdly excited for those seasons, at least one of which has been confirmed. Despite its faults the show is definitely an 8/10 and highly recommended.

Just thought I'd put in my two cents.
(v minor and deliberately vague spoilers)
Story: 6-7
I think it started off fairly strong, introducing a vibrant set of characters and interesting world building. The concept of the abyss is very interesting. But then it sets up the highly unrealistic idea of Riko, a 12-year-old red whistle who's at the bottom of the rung when it comes to skill and experience, going to the bottom of the abyss. Only the toughest adults armed with powerful weapons can head down to the lower levels and survive, so why will Riko be able to? She also wanted to go in solo,with no weapons. Even on the first level, Riko is helpless against the red beast. How is she expecting to fight the more dangerous beasts singlehandedly? I couldn't believe the notion that she was that dumb.


When the reasoning behind a centrepiece action which ultimately carries the series doesn't convince me, it really keeps nagging at me and makes it difficult to overlook. I'm not sure why I haven't seen anyone else point this out.


Even with Reg coming along, I found it very hard to believe this as realistic, even if this is a fantasy series. There's a clear system established for determining who has enough skill to delve deeper into the Abyss. Riko isn't exactly indicated to be some sort of prodigy so when this entire system is ignored, I'm not going to be persuaded that her survival is feasible. Their sole defence is his blaster, something that knocks his ass out for two hours. Yes, two solid hours with a handicap and no weapon. Even then, they sped through several whole levels without too many dangerous incidents. And in all of them, Reg is the one who manages to get them out safely. 


I think the Nanachi arc saved the story for me and pulled the score up from 4-5 to 7. It's packed with emotion and is solidly done, allowing the story to end off on a high note. 


All in all, I had an issue with the unrealistic storyline, but the Nanachi arc allowed it to redeem itself to some extent.


Art: 8/10

Great visuals in general, with lots of detail. The animation was also fairly smooth. 


Sound: 9/10

I loved the unique OSTs, which set the atmosphere of the story very effectively. The OP and ED were also fantastic.


Character: 6/10

For some reason, the story likes to introduce characters and focus on them for one or two episodes before forgetting about them completely. 


As aforementioned, I had issues with Riko's character. I know she isn't intended to be stupid, but she comes off as such. Reg is cool, I enjoyed his character. Nanachi is my personal favourite, being highly interesting and well-written. Would've liked to see more episodes on her.


Overall: 6-7/10

Despite the flaws in the series, there were also aspects that I enjoyed. Wouldn't have put it as anime of the year for me, but definitely had the material and potential to be if the issues I had were addressed. Would definitely check out the manga

I'm writing this right after finishing the show and really I only finished the show because of it's high rating and the MyAnimeList and r/anime groups thinking that this anime is the saviour of this season. But if not for these two communities upping the anime, I definetely wouldn't have finished it and after watching it through now, I don't think I would've missed out on much.
First off, lets start out with the parts of the show that I thought were good. The final episodes, though not perfect were better than the excurciatingly slow beginning/middle of the anime. The final episodes, starting realistically from somewherearound episode 10 is where the real shocking part of this show surfaces. It starts to become incredibly disturbing. Now while, yes, the things shown were disturbing, I ultimately felt there wasn't much point to them by the conclusion of the story or atleast the conclusion of this season. But, nonetheless these moments were exciting in a sort of horror movie jump scare type of way. But, the show could've focused more on stuff like this than what they were showing in the beggining of the show. 


Now, the bad parts of this for me can be summed up in it's bad/mediocre animation, boring/muddy artstyle, and the character dynamics between RIko and Reg (the main characters). The animation for one thing is incredibly inexpressive. Shows that I would consider expressive would be shows like Death Note, Hyouka, Zetsubo-sensei, Konsuba, and many many more. The things that these shows have is differing animation for different moments. Sometimes the characters might become chibi or they might get more detail for some effect or maybe there would be a close-up with increased animation for a movement or some stretch in the body for comedic effects or whatever. But Made In Abyss, this isn't the case. It felt the same whether they were fighting, hugging or whatever for a majority of the show. One example would be when they have this big haggard looking guy that comes looking for them and when he hugs them goodbye, I didn't really feel any emotional impact because I don't think it was expressed through animation in any meaninful way. Anime like Wolf Children, Garden of Sinners, and even World God Only Knows has better emotional hugging from the animation. 


Now, the artstyle too is just boring. It's pretty much just this dirt color with character designs that are extremely simple, even all the adult characters. When I first saw Riko's mother, I was frankly dissapointed. The simply artstyle is used well in other places like Madoka Magicka where there are scenes where it becomes much more abstract and the character designs then are in comparison fine (still not a huge fan though of the character art in Madoka)


 The characters are also a big problem. Riko is just unlikeable to me and her personality and her drive to go to the abyss seems artifical, like the writers needed her as a conduit to move the story forward and thus any scene with her felt kind of weird, cause I don't really see any chemistry between the heroine and the other characters. Now, disliking Riko is something that might just be personal to me. I don't know why but I don't like her positive attitude and the weird ass motif of her wetting her pants (I get it, this show is realistic and abrasive and all that but you don't have to keep showing it if there's no real point to it) and her obsession with the abyss. I found one character, Nanacci to be pretty decent (though not her design) and probably would've been better for the story if more of the focus was on her, atleast for more episodes. Another character that felt like bait to the viewers to sympathize/like was Ozen. I bet some people liked her and all that but like every other minor character, she just felt like filler to try to move the characters/story smoothly to lower levels of the abyss.


I find there's so much just small things about the show that I had issue with while watching it and after finishing it, i'm incredibly compelled to write my opinion, regardless of how unpolished or unpopular it is simply because I don't think this is a special anime by any means. There are shows that are more philosophical (Kino no Tabi, Serial Experiments Lain, paranoia agent), there are shows that are more disturbing (Kaiji, Madoka Magica, Kakegurui,berserk) and there are many many more shows with better pacing and plot.

I'm being completely honest when I give this a 10/10 in all aspects. Beautifully detailed art and animation, a soundtrack that sounds like something out of a Ghibli movie, and on top of it all a deeply compelling story hinting at something greater. I could write an entire book about my own speculations to the plot and attempts to detail the lore of the universe that Tsukushi has created.
Fair warning though, don't be fooled by the outwardly cheery nature the art style and sense of adventure bring. The rating is R+ for a very good reason. While it makes sense contextually and is censored toa degree, there is an uncomfortable amount of underage nudity, a shocking amount of blood and gore, and of course the psychological traumatizing of children. At times, it really seems like some old guy's sick pedo torture porn fantasy (I personally have no doubt of this actually).\n\n
And though, while I do severely doubt the moral integrity of its creator, that's really the only criticism I have of Made in Abyss. Looking strictly at it from a creative point of view, it really hits all the sweet spots of a scifi adventure. Robots, strange creatures living in a strange undocumented world, lost parents and tragic backstories, extremely driven main characters who will use any means possible to reach their goals, and most importantly, a cute bunny girl.

(No Spoilers) (Holistic review)
Made in Abyss is a anime that talks about a city next a big hole called “The Abyss”. The “Abyss” is a unknow underground place divided on 6 layers (that the human know), everyone with different aspects, with different creatures, plants. 
The Abyss has a powerfull curse, he creates effect on the human body depending on how deep you rises from him. The affects on the firsts layers are nausea, after hallucinations, after blood from the ears /eyes /mouth and deeper he have death /destruction /madness. In some point is considering “Impossible” for a normal human being to return from the deepestof the Abyss.


Inside the Abyss we can find multiple types of relics, like “magic objects”, and we have people that goes deep in this Abyss to bring this relic to surface achieving famous and money, this “famous and money” are so important the that hierarch on this city turns around the people that can reach the deeps of the Abyss, the most respescted people of the city are the “White whistles”: people who could reach the deepest of the Abyss and return alive to tell the secret.


This is the first coating of our plot, all this information is showed in the first two episodes with a good pace of narrative, I said this is the first coating, because we the plot revolves around the interaction of the Abyss with our character (our second coating on the plot).


Our characters are Riko (13 years old), the daughter of the white whistle Liza (the mom, that Riko wants to find, but we truly do not know how deep Liza is on the Abyss ), a Red Whistle (the lower rank on the society of the adventures, that can only go on the first layer of the Abyss) who on her Abyss exploration finds I humanoid robot called Reg (apparently 13 years old too), a robot with a good amount of power, resistance and intelligent, but with no memory of the pass, in orther words, we do not know the origin of Reg (but is kind of obvious that he comes from the abyss).


The set is clear, with Reg power and desire to know about himself, Riko together with Reg go down the Abyss to find her mother.


The plot and character dynamics on Made in Abyss is the fusion of this heavy atmosphere that The Abyss create and the desires of our characters. It’s a kind of obvious, but in Made in Abyss The Abyss itself is a element so strong in the creating of our characters development, and on the creation of the atmosphere (and the responsible for the immersion of the anime), that a I can only associate this strong cosmologic aspect on the anime Mushishi (2005, of the Director Nagahama Hiroshi). The Abyss creates his onw rules and creatures in a such strong way, that I can only argue that The Abyss is a cosmologic entity like the Mushi’s on Mushishi world.


The way that The Abyss decides which scene is for drama, or for the struggle, or for the appreciation, is so powerful, that we can not imagine our characters outside of this ambient. The Abyss on the anime is always portrayed as the most important thing of the humans beings (especialy for the explorers), and for us (wachters) The Abyss becomes the most important thing for our artistic appreciation. I can only sum up The Abyss in a “beautiful mystery” (almost like life ka ka).


As I said, the characters are two kids inside this Abyss, their dreams are embedded with The Abyss rules and creatures, Riko has a burn spirit, the true spirit for a Explorer of The Abyss and Reg is as mysterious as The Abyss, but someway the characters sounds less like a “beautiful mystery”, and more like normal happy characters we are used to. Sometimes you feel some dissonance with the childishness of the characters and the Abyss multivalent atmosphere, I do not know if this is purposeful, but I can say two things about this dissonance:


1- In the beginning, this childishness is kind of cute, but sometimes you do not feel this aspect fits on the atmosphere of the anime.


2- After some episodes (specifically, after ep 7-8) you can feel that the 


Abyss shapes our kids, the connection between then turns more clear and mature, and even the roles and the initial motivation grown up. And this is slow narrative aspect, and this maturing is the mark of the Director (Kojima Masayuki), Monster and Gunslinger Girl (especially this one) are two anime that we can feel that slow paced and we see some this slow characters maturing themselves (again, Gunslinger Girl is all about that I would say). 


I would say that characters development is too slow, but thanks to the Abyss we have one final break of this childishness on the second half of the anime (As I said beginning in the 7-8, and the perfect break point on the ep 10).


Everything I said could only be possible, because the art and sound of the Made in Abyss is stunning, the easiness to immerse on The Abyss atmosphere is the product of the art, never too dark, never too bright (you can see a good use of the shadows and lights, the insertion of this elements are very accurate) , we can see that the scenarios is not static, we can see the movement of the plants, little animals, water, the scenes transpired life. We have a scene on the ep 2, when Rico shows the city next to the Abyss to Reg, and like Reg, we can feel how this world is stunning and vivid.


Some things I could say about the soundtrack, Yamada You (the sound director), the same of "Kimi no na Wa" and "Garden of the Words", hits the target on Made in Abyss. In this kind of immersive anime, I prepare myself for something more chill, traditional and slow paced song (without complex arrangement, just simples and clear sounds, like on Mushishi soundtrack), but in Made in Abyss, the Mystery of the Abyss fits perfect on this contemplative soundtrack, the soundtrack is more emotional, like every scene on the Abyss is a new discovery, the creation of something new every time the characters interact with the Abyss.


The lyrics and rhythm of the opening fits perfect on the spirit of a adventure of kids (Riko and Reg) on a hard world like the Abyss, but on the first episode we are introduced to the Abyss and introduced to the song called “Underground River” . The same goes on a specific flashback on the ep 8 (soundtrack named “Hanazeke Caradhina”) where we see the a perfect harmony between a good song, a good art and even a good dubbing.


The dubbing is kind of different, our main, Riko, is dubbed by a young seyiuu (Tomita Miyu), the same of Gabriel (of Gabriel Dropout), Otako (Oshiete! Galko-chan) and Kuina (Hinako Note). She feets Riko young and energetic side, her voice while crying is very good. 


With Reg we have Mariya Ise, again another seyiuu that knows how to give life to a young character, but with some mature aspect (considering that Reg is in some way more realistic and cold than Riko), she was Misaki of Hyouka and she was Eureka of Pokemon YX .


If you want to see good voice, prepare yourself, in this show in have Lelouch Lamperouge, Onzen is Lelouch Lamperouge, the best voice of the anime, deep, strong and sharp, I can say that the voice Sayaka Ohara fits perfect on the atmosphere of The Abyss.


In the end, the only problem with Made in Abyss is the slow paced narrative and character development, Kojima always create this on me, sometimes I do not know if we have some evolution the plot or in the characters, because the narrative is so slow, detailed and holistic. But I can say that the Made in Abyss is the young brother of Mushishi, so is a anime that have a foundation on immersion, good art, good soundtrack and I perfect cosmologic aspect.

This anime is just beautiful, the soundtrack is perfect everytime it sound, the story and the scenes fills you with sadness and melancholy just to change into a heartwarming atmosphere, even if the characters are child-looking style, it just make them (and their expressions) feel more realistic.
You can totally watch the character development while the story isprogressing and perfectly understand the intentions and the chemistry between them (specially in Riko and Reg, the protegonists)
Is so entertaining and pleasurable to watch that if you read, you would think that it wouldn't be enough to show everything the autor wanted.
I would totally say that this is oneof the best animes in the past years and now, of course, one of my favorites \n

Made in Abyss, The dark horse of the season, and probably of the year. There was something about this anime that made me look forward to it, before the season even started. And surely, it did not disappoint. It became one of the most memorable anime of the year, probably one of the best fantasy anime I've come across and easily the anime of the summer. 
Made in Abyss is a breathtaking adventure that paints the explosion of a creation's imagination with a story that is dark, depressing, interesting, unpredictable and EXTREMELY creative. The fear of the unknown, not many shows I can say havepulled it off as good. The setting of the abyss, it's layers, the concepts such as the curse of the abyss, whistles of cave raiders, and the different creatures and the way those creatures work from a fantasy standpoint to a biological standpoint are so well thought out and structured, hats off the creator Tsukushi Akihito, who did outdid himself creating such a detailed environment that is unpredictable, grand, scary, confusing (in a good way) and claustrophobic. I love the pacing of the story, it progresses significantly better with each episode but it's never too much that you can't digest or too less to not fill you up.


The characters are what make the show a lot more fun, they are cute and provide comedic relief, especially two of the main three, Reg and Riko who get most of the screentime. But although they look cute I must say some of things they do and their experiences, their background are quite mature, almost quite depressing. I don't want to spoil and I'm not going to but There is one scene in the second half that really fucked me up. I knew I was in for something dark but that was beyond anything I had expected. The side characters and the ones they meet in their journey are pretty interesting as well, they all have something unique which makes it notable that they are part of that environment, they are diverse and what they offer to the story is quite interesting, I gotta say about all their dresses, it's kind of like a mix of modern and historic design.


The art and animation is fantastic as well, Probably the best work of Kinema Citrus. Beautiful landscapes, great usage of color, they've done justice to the microscopic detail of the abyss, The action scenes really show the effort they put into each frame, it's just smooth as fuck. Don't even get me started on the musical score and insert songs, they had this english song playing in the first episode, it automatically tells you shit is going to be epic! some of the sound effects like when reg is blasting his hand ray or whatever it's called and that extra bass sound that they give when they're trouble, it adds so much to the overall experience. The voice acting is too cartoony though, especially notable in Ouzen's character, but it kinda works, almost like it is perfectly blending a kid show with something that a kid shouldn't be anywhere near of.


My only problem with this anime is that I was left wanting for more, I would've preferred this to be 20+ episodes and with the momentum and popularity that it has been buiding throughout the course of the season, I'm sure it would have helped the studio that is yet to make a commercial super hit, This might be the one for Kinema citrus. And each episode has like a four minute outro and the two minute ED which took away 6 minutes of the entire episode, gladly it didn't mess with the overall pacing of the show. 


Made in Abyss does a great job balancing it's light and dark elements and providing content that is both grand and heavy, executing it almost flawlessly that resulted in a show that is simply pure value for entertainment. Do yourself a favor and go watch this stunner.

This is a good show and certainly worth watching, though I definitely have some qualms with it.
The absolute best thing about this show is the world, Akihito Tsukushi has created a unique, memorable, vibrant world within and around The Abyss and I want to learn more about every small detail that gets introduced fleetingly or otherwise. What brings down the overall story in my eyes is that the characters who are the focus don't interest me terribly. I do want to know more about Reg but I'm not compelled by Riko's story. In fact one of my larger problems with the show is Riko's defenselessness.She is clearly not suited to travel the Abyss (to be fair that is kind of the plot) but to a point where it's almost comical how easily she is able to navigate downward despite constantly being told "oh you'll die in like 10 seconds in the third layer!" only to have Reg robo their way through it while she sits idly by. If you want to show her growth as a character then do more to show her trying, failing, learning, and succeeding rather than immediately yell for Reg and have him sort out literally everything except cooking. I'm glad she has a defined personality but her recklessness only got her in serious trouble once from what I can remember and while she doesn't escape the season free from harm she does seem to have some serious plot armor. I'm not saying that I need to see characters maimed and punished for their actions, but when you stress how dangerous the creatures of the Abyss are I expect that a reckless character diving deeper into the Abyss will learn and grow more cautious as the episodes go by, something that Riko does not do in the slightest in this season.


One character who tried to have her exercise more caution, the white whistle Ozen, was one of my favorite characters despite that fact that I kind of hate her. In fact Ozen succeeds because I hate her character as she denies typical mentor tropes. In general the few white whistles we've seen have captivated me because of how much they break the mold of typical role models for main characters, the two that we learned the most about were pretty despicable which makes me curious as to how Lyza will be portrayed when we finally begin to learn more about her outside of the brief flashbacks we have received. 


The biggest drawback is the show's weird fixation on children's genitals. I'm not going to mince words they focus far far too much attention on Reg's penis. And Riko's urinary habits. In fact if they were to just utterly remove those scenes from the show I would likely rate this an 8/10 rather than a 7/10. The scenes are just too prominent, occur more than a single time, and are frankly uncomfortable in a way that doesn't feel intentional the way certain other scenes do in the back half of the season. 


Nevertheless I will happily watch a second season and just have to do my best to ignore the inevitable scenes where an adult meets a robot child and immediately stares down his pants. Or the inevitable scenes where the three prepubescent main characters get naked and prod each other and ask the same genital related questions for the 4th 5th 6th times. If you think I'm stressing this too much then just wait until the show beats you over the head with it episode after episode. I don't blame anyone for dropping Made in Abyss for these reasons. 


I can also understand the people who, despite my feelings, believe this show is outstanding, it has a lot of good things to mention. The individual layers of the Abyss are like something out of a Monolith Soft world and are all unique from each other and from other media. The creatures in the Abyss and their ecosystem are fascinating and we only get little glances at them. Nanachi has a tragic and compelling story and I want to see it play out even if it doesn't end happily (as I suspect it won't because this show took a Gen Urobuchi-esque turn that I was kind of expecting but was still welcome). Nanachi's arc, which was introduced late, was easily the most compelling thing that I felt the show had to offer aside from the world building. The orphanage above the Abyss isn't terribly interesting but I do want to see where they're going with the birthday disease. 


As I said before Made In Abyss is worth your time but it is not without fault. It is a good show that is set up to have a second season better than the first and could easily make the step into being a series that I believe is great.

I started to see Made In Abyss because it had gained in its first episodes a certain popularity in the most critical world of the anime for its interesting history and world, and in relation to this its world-build.
Story: 10/10
Going by part, the story of Made In Abyss is extremely creative, versatile and respectable with the rules that the series establishes, but despite this it maintains throughout the series its atmosphere of mystery and that magical air despite the different twists of nuts and moments of 'shock' that it has. Everything starts in 'Orth' a city that was built next toa huge hole in which the background is not known and is intensely researched by subjects called 'Cave Raiders' who are researchers / warriors / survivors of the dangers of the abyss, these Cave Raiders are divided into 5 classes which are called 'Whistle' plus a color forward (red-blue-lunar-black-white). Throughout the series, the plot changes a lot, starting as something very magical, to advance in a science fiction environment and end up in a very dark environment. But what I value is that 'Made In Abyss' does not force this at any time and everything flows at a perfect pace in the narrative and every situation that passes has a cause previously warned and with an enormous respect for its own rules without falling into conveniences, such as the Deus Ex Machina, a mysterious help from nothing, something unimportant that has happened before without clarifying that it leads to a senseless help in some aspect, among others ... All the ideas that make up 'Made In Abyss 'as the idea of ​​the abyss in layers, with a well-armed magical realism, and the' Cave Raiders' system is extremely creative and interesting, in turn all this is used in a precise way to properly exploit your world, layer by layer without staying so long there to result in something overloaded, or without being unnecessarily fast, and most of the operation of each layer had been previously explained, without passing a detail. This shows that the writing and direction are sublime, in addition to being creative and interesting that engage the one who sees immediately regardless of the story arc. There are people who complain that the world of Made In Abyss is an exit trap like a mysterious box, but I do not see it that way, because the good world-build that it possesses makes it irrelevant, in addition to the fact that the abyss itself is the main plot of the story, that argument would work if something irrelevant to the plot kept you hooked, but it is not so for what argument, also the mystery is something that adds to make everything more interesting. On the other hand, Made In Abyss adds many points in its history for its originality, it has a world that has never been seen, it mixes genres, the concept of Cave Raiders and its system is very creative, the idea of ​​the abyss with influences of literature Classic and magical realism of Ghibli are also very original. And the concept of adventure unfolds very well, as they exploit every part of the world and as I said above, the regulation system of the series is very remarkable and it hooks you to the plot without you feeling empty at some point because they know how to give you information at a good pace, perhaps the third layer if it is more empty but taking into account that the rules and operation of each layer have been explained and still give you information, I do not think it is negative to give more importance to what would be to the arc of Nanachi.


Art: 10/10


The art is possibly the strongest section of Made In Abyss in a complete way, visually the direction is splendid and it mixes painting techniques and a beautiful drawing that makes everything very attractive visually, as well as the environmental art of each layer in the which, the use of lights / shadows or the use of colors make the immersion even better compared to the construction of the world.


Sound: 10/10


The sound / soundtrack / ost of Made In Abyss is amazing, the sounds used work very well, but the soundtrack is impeccable that would work not only as a soundtrack, but as an individual music album, being varied in genres mixing neo-classical, folk, touches of electronics and Japanese folklore very well crafted, plus the arrangements are beautiful.


Characters: 7/10


The characters are probably the weakest section of the series, but it does not mean they are bad, they are very good, but they fall short sometimes. Although each character does contribute to the plot to elaborate it and have several facets to acquire a good empathy towards them, sometimes they tend to waste all their potential, besides that Reg could have given more, it is not something that criticizes much. the importance of Reg in the story that is elaborated later, but other than that is fine. In addition both protagonists complement each other very well, learn from their mistakes, and make good decisions despite how hard they could be. Another problem of the characters, is that most are not three-dimensional characters, although if there are 2 that are (Nanachi and Bondrewd), the majority remains in two-dimensional, it is a fact that they are not flat and that they contribute to the plot, but potential is often wasted, as with adults. I agree that the lack of adults or rather, their lack of presence seems strange, although the world states that the Cave Raiders have a rigorous training to survive, I feel that the potential of adults as a guide in difficult situations such as Ozen It could be better used. Although Reg and Riko are children, it does not seem like a bad concept, because it is precisely used well as even criticism and message. In addition to that the co-protagonists do not lose the balance of an innocence of someone of their age as Reg to be somewhat fragile personality or curiosity of their world, but in turn have those aspects of preparation of cave raiders that allow you to take good decisions.


Others:


Another problem is the Reg's Joke, is a joke that is irrelevant to the plot for good and bad, on the one hand does not hurt the plot, but on the other it takes seriousness to certain situations when the context don't need it. And for obvious reasons is an awful joke.


My conclusion is that Made In Abyss is an excellent series, that although it has its faults, it has a lot to contribute to the modern anime, since it has the artistic sense, courage and originality to be able to develop a good and interesting plot, but at the same time without losing his excellent art that is something that constantly strikes us.


Overall: 9.4/10 = 9/10
