Historia: 10/10


Yendo por partes, la historia de Made In Abyss es extremadamente creativa, versátil y respetable con las reglas que establece la serie, pero a pesar de esto mantiene a través de la serie su atmósfera de misterio y ese aire mágico a pesar de los diferentes giros de frutos secos y momentos de 'shock' que tiene. Todo comienza en 'Orth', una ciudad que fue construida al lado de un gran agujero en el que el fondo no es conocido y es intensamente investigado por sujetos llamados 'Cave Raiders' que son investigadores / guerreros / sobrevivientes de los peligros del abismo, estos Cave Los incursores se dividen en 5 clases que se llaman 'silbido' más un color hacia adelante (rojo-azul-lunar-negro-blanco). A lo largo de la serie, la trama cambia mucho, comenzando como algo muy mágico, para avanzar en un entorno de ciencia ficción y terminar en un entorno muy oscuro. Pero lo que valoro es que 'Made In Abyss' no lo fuerza en ningún momento y todo fluye a un ritmo perfecto en la narración y cada situación que pasa tiene una causa previamente advertida y con un enorme respeto por sus propias reglas sin caer en conveniencias, como el Deus Ex Machina, una misteriosa ayuda de la nada, algo sin importancia que ha sucedido antes sin aclarar que conduce a una ayuda sin sentido en algún aspecto, entre otros... Todas las ideas que componen 'Made In Abyss' como la idea del abismo en capas, con un realismo mágico bien armado, y el sistema de 'Cave Raiders' es extremadamente creativo e interesante, a su vez todo esto se usa de una manera precisa para explotar adecuadamente su mundo. capa sin permanecer tanto tiempo allí como para dar lugar a algo sobrecargado, o sin ser innecesariamente rápido, y la mayor parte del funcionamiento de cada capa se había explicado previamente, sin pasar ningún detalle. Esto muestra que la escritura y la dirección son sublimes, además de ser creativas e interesantes que comprometen a quien ve de inmediato independientemente del arco de la historia. Hay personas que se quejan de que el mundo de Made In Abyss es una trampa de salida como una caja misteriosa, pero no lo veo así, porque la buena construcción del mundo que posee la hace irrelevante, además del hecho de que el El abismo mismo es la trama principal de la historia, ese argumento funcionaría si algo irrelevante para la trama te mantiene enganchado, pero no es así para qué argumento, también el misterio es algo que se agrega para hacer que todo sea más interesante. Por otro lado, Made In Abyss agrega muchos puntos en su historia por su originalidad, tiene un mundo que nunca se ha visto, mezcla géneros, el concepto de Cave Raiders y su sistema es muy creativo, la idea del abismo con influencias de la literatura El realismo clásico y mágico de Ghibli también es muy original. Y el concepto de aventura se desarrolla muy bien, ya que explotan cada parte del mundo y como dije antes, el sistema de regulación de la serie es muy notable y te engancha a la trama sin que te sientas vacío en algún momento porque saben cómo para darle información a un buen ritmo, tal vez la tercera capa si está más vacía pero teniendo en cuenta que las reglas y el funcionamiento de cada capa se han explicado y todavía le dan información, no creo que sea negativo darle más importancia a lo que sería para el arco de Nanachi.


Arte: 10/10


El arte es posiblemente la sección más fuerte de Made In Abyss de una manera completa, visualmente la dirección es espléndida y mezcla técnicas de pintura y un hermoso dibujo que hace que todo sea muy atractivo visualmente, así como el arte ambiental de cada capa en la que, el uso de luces / sombras o el uso de colores hacen que la inmersión sea aún mejor en comparación con la construcción del mundo.


Sonido: 10/10


El sonido/banda sonora/ost de Made In Abyss es increíble, los sonidos usados ​​funcionan muy bien, pero la banda sonora es impecable y funcionaría no solo como banda sonora, sino como álbum de música individual, variando en géneros mezclando neoclásico, folk, toques de electrónica y folklore japonés muy bien elaborados, además los arreglos son hermosos.


Personajes: 7/10


Los personajes son probablemente la sección más débil de la serie, pero no significa que sean malos, son muy buenos, pero a veces se quedan cortos. Aunque cada personaje contribuye a la trama para elaborarlo y tiene varias facetas para adquirir una buena empatía hacia ellos, a veces tienden a perder todo su potencial, además de que Reg podría haber dado más, no es algo que critique demasiado. la importancia de Reg en la historia que se elabora más adelante, pero aparte de eso está bien. Además, ambos protagonistas se complementan muy bien, aprenden de sus errores y toman buenas decisiones a pesar de lo difícil que pueden ser. Otro problema de los personajes, es que la mayoría no son personajes tridimensionales, aunque si hay 2 que son (Nanachi y Bondrewd), la mayoría permanece en dos dimensiones, es un hecho que no son planos y que contribuyen a la trama, pero el potencial a menudo se pierde, como con los adultos. Estoy de acuerdo en que la falta de adultos o más bien, su falta de presencia parece extraña, aunque el mundo afirma que los Cave Raiders tienen un entrenamiento riguroso para sobrevivir, siento que el potencial de los adultos como guía en situaciones difíciles como Ozen podría ser mejor utilizado. Aunque Reg y Riko son niños, no parece un concepto malo, porque se usa con precisión, incluso como crítica y mensaje. Además de eso, los coprotagonistas no pierden el equilibrio de la inocencia de alguien de su edad como Reg por ser algo frágil, la personalidad o la curiosidad de su mundo, pero a su vez tienen esos aspectos de la preparación de los asaltantes de cuevas que le permiten tomar buenas decisiones


Otros:


Otro problema es la broma de Reg, es una broma que es irrelevante para la trama para bien y para mal, por un lado no daña la trama, pero por otro toma seriedad para ciertas situaciones y daña el contexto. Y por obvias razones es molesto.


Mi conclusión es que Made In Abyss es una serie excelente, que aunque tiene sus fallas, tiene mucho que aportar al anime moderno, ya que tiene el sentido artístico, el coraje y la originalidad para poder desarrollar un argumento bueno e interesante, pero al mismo tiempo sin perder su excelente arte que es algo que constantemente nos golpea.


Total: 9,4/10 = 9/10

Every year or so, there come titles which seem to push the anime industry further and further to being more than what many perceive it to be. 
2017's Made In Abyss (MIA as I will be abbreviating it through this review) seems to fit that mold and then some. With beautiful and expressive animation, gorgeous art, wonderful music, all within a world of characters and narrative which make it a true stand out among it's contemporaries. And the best part... There's only one season out at the time of this review with a second on the way. And if this first entry into the seriesis any indicator, it will continue to be great.


The best way I could fastball pitch MIA's to anyone is this: If HP Lovecraft, Don Bluth and Hayo Miyazaki were to given the task to craft a narrative production together, this would be the end result. And through it's 13 episode run, we get that just as you'd imagine it to be.



The story is built around the mystery of the eponymous setting of the Abyss and how our two main characters, Riko and Reg, discover it's many secrets and mysteries on the path to find Riko's mother said to be down in the Abyss. What the two face are wild dangers and many revelations that reveal much about the Abyss and the lives they grew up in. That's as much as I can go into without diving into spoiler territory. But through the narrative, there's a great utilization of show don't tell when it comes to the setting. A wondrous bit of mystery overtakes each scene. It always leaves you wanting to research and learn more. And every step it takes is so convicting.

The characters are all also wonderful. While some do remain a bit on the under-developed side (hopefully Season 2 will rectify that), you still feel their impact and remember their name and face. And the characters we do see develop and grow are some of the best written in anime or any form of fiction. The more we see them go through and learn, the more intriguing and likable they become. And boy do these characters go through ALLOT!


The art and animation in the series is also gorgeous. Nothing seems processed and instead painted on and pops. Lots of great lighting, color, and vibrant style to it all to help bring a sense of beauty and often times horror to the world. The animation is also nice with great, expressive characters, non-stotic animation and movement and a design choice that really helps to contrast to the tone of the series overall giving it that extra bit of uniqueness.


The music is one of the best soundtracks in anime. Kevin Pelkin (who previously did work for Under The Dog), really gets to shine here. Great choir work and wonderful instrumental all throughout. All with a great OP and ED. All his songs give me goosebumps and should prove to the same effect.


Overall, Made In Abyss may have some shortcomings due to it's 13 episode act, leaving some characters and plots left to dangle, but with the announcement of season 2, it should prove to expand upon those elements and the other narrative elements even more. I really enjoyed this series all in all and 100% recommend anyone check it out. (Warning: The series can get pitch-black dark and depressing much of it. So if you're not into that, either give it a pass or be warned)

When I watch a fantasy anime or read a fantasy story, I want to learn about the world that is being introduced to me. I want to explore the inner depths of everything that is present in this world, I want to know how people survive there, what the rules and guidelines are, but most importantly, I want to see how this world functions in the first place. Made in Abyss does all of this and more. 
From the very beginning, the show had me completely immersed in the world and characters. The way we are first introduced to the Abyss (and the world ingeneral) is not by a narrator explicitly telling us what it is and how it functions, but by observing by ourselves how the Abyss functions on a day-to-day basis, and how normal humans interact with it. This immediately adds an exciting, yet slightly intimidating, layer of the unknown to the world. The way the show set it up had me craving more instantly, and wanting to understand how exactly everything functioned. 

This is what I want to see with fantasy worlds, something that is special in its own way and not just a generic universe with magic and some goblins. The animals and plants that are inside the Abyss are all unique in their own way and seem to actually function and corporate together like a real, proper ecosystem, and each individual layer of the Abyss is exclusive to its universe and always kept me excited for what was happening next. Throughout the entire show, I was constantly rooting for Reg and Riko, anxious for their survival, and apprehensive as to how they would deal with new challenges. The writer was truly a genius and made sure that each part of the Abyss had events that were natural set up and different for each layer. 


The fact that almost all the characters (and both of the main characters) were all children definitely helped set the overall tone for the series. Children are generally curious, and it does make a lot of sense to put them into a world that is filled to the brim with mysteries for them to figure out on their own. Reg and Riko were very compatible with each other, and they were designed in such a way that made them balance one another out. Both of them had very fleshed out and well-defined personalities. The supporting cast was, in general, fairly forgettable, but I enjoyed watching Reg and Riko interact with them, anyways.


The soundtrack was amazing and really fit with each scene. I was constantly listening to the OST weeks after I had finished the show, it was just that good. 


The art was breathtaking and complemented the nature of the Abyss. On the surface, the art style was cute and bubbly with characters that had chibi like proportions and faces, however, it could just as quickly turn dark and gruesome. The backgrounds were amazing, and the characters were very expressive and lively. 


All in all, the only thing that I was dissatisfied within Made in Abyss was the fact that the ending was open-ended, and cuts off halfway through the manga. Other than that, though, the show was amazing. It was able to deliver a very emotional impact on me and exceeded my expectations. It had great strengths in almost every catogory, and very few, minor weaknesses. It serves as a great example that all fantasy anime should follow, I would absolutely reccomend the show.

Made in Abyss is a 13 episode anime adaptation of a manga of the same name with it's rampant success thankfully green-lighting more to come. The story tells something close to about half of what the manga has covered so far and has done so extremely faithfully ,and at some points it did so in more detail than the respective scenes in the manga did. There were some minor story elements and side plot that seemed to be added as I didn't come across it in the manga however it was wonderfully done, enrichedthe world, and I'm sure the manga's author Tsukuchi Akihito gave the additions and changes a go ahead or suggested them himself to promote a more cohesive story.


I will address a few aspects that may have stalled my enjoyment of MiA as the story seems to either receive harsh criticism or overwhelming praise. There is very little I have to complain about with this show. First, the plot is very straight forward and that isn't a bad thing. While it is simple and seemingly a linear goal for our protagonists it still manages to get muddy as to just WHAT Riko and Reg are seeking to achieve on their journey though. My only real complaint with this world is that every adult in the story seems to just be totally cool with this 11-13 year old girls perilous death journey, but in a way every persons fervor and acceptance of the harsh world they live in could be explained by the pseudo-eldritch aura the setting gives off.


Second, let us address all the child nudity and dialogue. I think the only grievance to be had with this work is that Tsukuchi's depiction of the sexuality of budding adolescence is done well enough that it would make anyone feel a little uncomfortable. To me it just reminds me how sexually weird and awkward I was at 12 which is uncomfortable at worst and goofy at best. Do not be deceived by this anime's appearance - Made in Abyss is to anime what Watchmen is to superhero movies. The story is so simple, yet compelling, what lies at the bottom of the Abyss? The fantasy world created here is one for the ages, every scene is filled with such a breathtaking mystique that it cannot be adequately described, only witnessed.
Story:
The temptation of the unknown is strong, and Made in Abyss strikes that yearning hidden in all of us with an expert hand, weaving an enchanting backstory entwined with memorable, human, characters. Like the Abyss itself, the plot begins with lighthearted themes andtypical anime earnestness, and slowly peels away at that facade to reveal the full breadth of its message.


Art:

Made in Abyss looks wonderful throughout, with a style and flair that reminds me of Studio Ghibli films like Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind and Princess Mononoke. I especially appreciate the water color form some of the creatures take in movement, which was a brilliant and tasteful way to efficiently create animation without resorting to CG that can often ruin immersion.


Sound:

The music that flowed along with the pacing of the story was beautiful, enhancing rather than distracting from what was occurring on screen. Props to whoever put those pieces together.


Character:

Riko and Regu are two of the most adorable, yet equally rich, characters I have encountered in fiction. The bonds they form with everyone around them feel genuine and believable, and the audience is given little choice but to become deeply invested in their well being.


All of the supporting cast are brilliant in their own way, from the mysterious Ouzen to the dulcet tones of Habo, many of them would be deserving of more screen time if not for Riko and Regu.


Enjoyment:

Certainly a contender for strongest anime of 2017, Made in Abyss hides its blinding greatness behind a chibi mask that may ward off some, PLEASE GIVE IT A CHANCE to show you itself!

Story:
Made in Abyss has an incredible storyline that captivates you from the start--so much mystery and a sense of unknown. It makes you wanting more by the end of it
Art:
Very visually pleasing! Though the "chibi" style art isn't really my thing, I got used to it a few episodes in. 
Sound:
One of the best soundtracks ever. So, SO good. I can't rave about it enough 
Enjoyment: 
Couldn't get enough!
Overall:
Few shows have left me with the feeling of wanting to rewatch it. I gave the manga a try, but this is one of those where the anime really, really improves on the manga. It's a masterpiece

This review won't contain any spoilers. Also, I will make it as clear and concise as possible.
I'll admit I wasn't sure about this anime at first, and yes, it was because of the looks. The premise was appealing to me, but the characters felt somewhat childish. I thought, "This may be boring to me." Thankfully, I didn't allow myself to be fooled by appearances. I'm sure many people could feel the same when considering if they should give this show a chance.
I will not say this anime is a masterpiece, because I think that would be exaggerating (although the next chapter of the story couldround things up). In fact, I think this show may be a little overrated. However, what an adult like me can expect from Made in Abyss (and let me clarify, this is not a children's show), I think it provides. What I mean, plainly, is this:

- A journey of discovery about the mystery of the Abyss: its nature, its unique wildlife, the enigmatic relics buried in its depths, the relentless "Curse of the Abyss"...

- Innocent main characters (they are children, after all), nothing too special about their personalities, that the show complements with darker backgrounds in some other characters. 

- The show and the nature of the Abyss appear simpler at the start, like the children we follow, but things get more complex and interesting as we go deeper into the show, and into the Abyss.

- A variety of emotion-packed moments and scenes: warm, funny, thrilling, chilling, sad...  


In the end, I enjoyed this anime plenty. It promised adventure and mystery, fantasy and realism, drama and warmth... and I think it delivered. Whether it could have done better or not, I'll leave for you to decide. My personal opinion is that some things would have been more appealing to me if they had been a little bit different, but I don't want to delve into possibly irrelevant details (and spoilers). After all, that's a matter of taste. Ultimately, I enjoyed the journey I experienced, and the last episode left me wanting to watch more, to know more. I hope we will receive a second, exciting season as soon as the source material allows. 


In summary, appearances can be deceiving. The show itself reminds us this more than once. So think twice about rejecting this show if you like the genre. As we descend and discover more about the story, the Abyss and all the characters, the show reveals itself as a piece of entertainment that is more full than it looks.

This is the second review I have ever written (first being on Toradora).
Made in Abyss is a "seinen" anime meaning that the anime is for adults. Personally this is my favorite anime of 2017. It is produced by Kinema Citrus the same studio that brought us Black Bullet (2014).
Made in Abyss at a glance seems like a cute adventure anime but as the anime progresses it starts to reveal its underlying dark and perilous journey. The anime starts with two young orphans exploring caves while searching for relics to give to their orphanage so they can keep for display or use for profit. 
The animeis centered cave raiding and exploring for relics or treasures. There is a giant pit in the center of the city that is broken down into 7 layers, the further down you traverse the more dangerous and life threatening the environment and beasts become. MIA gives you subtle hints of what lies underneath each layer which is where it's mystery comes in but you don't quite know exactly what lies down there until you get there.


Riko and Reg decide to go on a quest searching for Riko's mother a prestigious cave raider whose existence is unknown. 


One of the things that makes this anime interesting that separates from others is the fact that the conflict is actually the dangerous of the Abyss itself rather than there being an main antagonist.  There is also a lot of love and care about each other between Riko and Reg which keeps the viewer emotionally invested as the anime explores themes of friendship, trust, sadness, and death.


I found the story to be very intriguing making me want to binge watch each episode right after the previous one had ended. A downside to this series is it's still on going meaning the anime ends on episode 13 with an incomplete story that is presumably going to continue with a following season.


A large portion of humor used in this anime is sexual situations among children, which in all honesty seems fitting given how children can be immature (a reoccurring example of this being how Reg is a robot but he has a realistic penis, as he also has human features). The issue with the humor used in this anime is it sometimes conflicts with it's serious tone breaking the tension of danger.


The production value of this anime is really good. It's not the best I have seen (in my opinion No Game No Life looks better) but I was surprised after the first episode how good the series looks and blends well with it's sounds and sound track. The style this anime uses looks like high quality chibi animation with vibrant colors.


From the top of my head this the 2nd great adventure anime I have seen the 1st being No Game No Life and I would say in terms of enjoyment and production value it goes head-to-head with NGNL, the one area where I feel MIA excels at is keeping you intrigued in its mystery wondering what's going to happen next. I feel like pacing of MIA is perfect, it's neither too fast nor too slow.


One disclaimer I do give people interested in this series is prepare themselves for blood and gore and intense scenes. Instead of happening right away it instead tries tries to ease you into it making each episode more life threatening than the previous one. It does reach levels of disturbing and for me personally it made one scene unwatchable making me fast forward the scene. The blood and gore, however, never feels unnecessary.


Overall I rate this anime as a 9 out of 10. Making it just as good or better than No Game No Life and also marking this as my favorite anime of 2017.

There are many aspects that contribute to the mysterious beauty that is Made In Abyss. One of which is the first thing you'll experience going into the introductory episode. The incredibly detailed and beautiful environment, influenced by the original creator of the story Tshukushi Akihito which embraces or should i say swallows up the viewer.  But personally one of the better aspects had to be the scripting and writing, for one the narration that was done my Maaya Sakamoto, is one of the best I've heard in a extremely long time. It not only did a magnificent job reinforcing the mysteryand drama through out the story but it wasn't overbearing either. 


Now when if comes to the conversations and interactions  between our two main characters Riko and reg. You could not of  found or made a better partnership. The amount of friendship and trust between these two is unparalleled.  Which is why when the drama starts it hits us with incredible impact.  Because when we see strong characters like these two suffer, it makes us think. "How can this happen?! Come on you have to make it through this."  


There are also some really wonderful supporting characters that get introduced, who play an incredible role in adding elements to the story. This is where I need to get credit to the voicing cast because the voice is what makes the character. Ohara Sayaka who voiced the roll of Ozen did a magnificent job, keeping the audience on edge with her very menacing yet straight forward demeanor and tone. But if you were to ask me which two characters I feel had the most impact, they would have to be Riko and Nanachi.  Tomita Miyu confident and cheerful tone mad Riko a very lovable character that we would want to empathize with and support. While Shiori Izawa's role as the sarcastic nanachi, not only surprised us with a very compassionate and selfless side to the character but introduced us to one of the most dramatic and heartfelt backs stories in the series. 


The character designs, which were handled by Kise Kazuchika, did an excelent job making us fall inlove with the characters. Even for some of the more minor supporting ones like Kiyui who is one of my personal favorites.  A huge factor that plays into this  is how some of the orphanage children look younger then what they really are. For example, becoming a red whistle starts at the age of twelve. But just by looking at the children you would assume their 7-9 years old at the oldest. This is why there is a strong since of discomfort though out the story and why the drama in it is so powerful.


It's the the same disturbing thought of taking small defenseless children and  placing them in an very unsettling and unpredictable environment to fend for themselves, that makes us feel weary and nervous through out riko and regs journey. 


Now the creature design are a work of art of all their own. Each living thing from the abyss, was designs by Kou Yoshinari and added it's very own since of discovery and unknown danger to the story.  Now the Animation for the series, was handled by Studio Kinema Citrus and aided by the incredible direction of  Kise Kuzuchika who is known for his excellent work in series like  Escaflowne and Evangelion. 


But nothings compares to the incredibly beautiful sound track that was composed by Kevin Penkin. His music really did a magnificent job, bringing out the magic in each scene and the emotional investment we have in the story. And from my own personal experience, no matter how many times I listen to it while watching, it never seized to move and captivate me. 


Made in Abyss is  incredibly captivating watch,  filled with wonderful characters, and a story that is so profoundly moving and beautiful that you have to experience it for yourself. So I urge you, if you haven't done so already take the challenge and journey into the Abyss.

When I started this anime, I was not instantly hooked. I liked the concept and the setting. But I had little familiarity with the characters. The art was not Madhouse caliber even though the whole fantasy world provided a lot of scope for it. And so I consumed the first few episodes at slow pace not really sure if I should keep at it. But a character driven fiction like Made in Abyss requires some investment of time and patience to comprehend the fullness of its glory.
But then this show started to grow on me, slowly but surely. Miko's tenacious optimism, Reg's overwhelming compassion, theirindestructible camaraderie along with the finely sculpted supporting characters transformed this what initially seemed like a children's fantasy drama into a gem that shed's light on the nature of humanity.


The Abyss is an epitome of everything in Nature that challenges humanity in mankind. In face of such monumental challenges, how do we hold on to our body, mind and soul? I believe this is the question that pervades the entire show as it seeks to find an answer to this ever-looming question, as the protagonists journey down the abyss seeking their answers to their own questions.


I'd recommend this show to any seasoned anime lover. If you are a fan of "Now and Then, Here and There", "Shinsekai Yori" or "Planetes" then you'll not regret picking this one up.

Probably one of the greatest written and technically executed 3 episode openings ever made and the show doesn't let go from there. What the show drops a bit in technical storytelling quality it makes up for with this insane and crazy premise that draws you into the abyss and makes you wonder whats down inside and why it's there. The world is why you get invested in this show. For a while in anime (to me at least) fantasy has lost that fantastical feel to it. Most contemporary fantasy anime are set in more of a Tolkein style of world with the label of fantasy.While yeah, its got mythical and magical creatures and magic and whatever else that's not really fantasy in the way that fantasy once captured me. This is a world that has existed for a long time but there are still elements of this world that are still unknown and that just draws you in because of those elements. Couple the world with top tier gore and action scenes that have insane consequences for our characters and a world that needs to be experienced just dive in and enjoy the ride.

I don't know why, I had a really hard time finishing this anime. Not for lack of trying, I was promised a masterpiece and it hit all the right notes from the get go: interesting premise, charming atmosphere, gorgeous setting and what felt like an absolute breath of fresh air compared to the average show.
And it didn't click. 
Even though it was wonderful, there was no real drive to keep me going. I needed to trudge (and it honestly felt like a struggle) through two thirds of the show before I could actually look forward to the next episode. 
If I had to point outwhat was the problem, I'd say it was the two main characters we were left with after the first episode eclipsed. They're not bad at all, but they need to carry most of the episodes and I felt that there needed to be more substance. Some extra characters are introduced along the way  and yeah, it helps, but they didn't stick around for too long. \n\n
When we begin to get into more interesting parts of the abyss and our next big character is introduced the anime picks up fast. Stories become intertwined, questions arise and character interactions become more emotional. \n\n
So even though I appreciate what the show tried (and succeeded by the looks of what most people think) to bring to the table, I'm afraid I wasn't able to partake in it as fully as I would have wanted to.

First of all please note that this is no means for children to watch even though it's protagonists are children. Also by no means expect a light-hearted fun filled adventure anime here, if so then you have been completely deceived as well as I was. There are strong adult themes present which just skyrockets towards the end. 
Now talking about deceived, to be completely honest I found the first to mid parts of the anime (speaking specifically  about episodes 1-8) literally quite boring to an extent that makes me question why do I even bother. Yeah it has an interesting plot as well assolid motive for the female protagonist Riko to pursue her descend down the Abyss which is nice to follow but it became a bit of a struggle to watch them navigate down each layer. Parts do end up becoming like a rise-and-repeat a fair which is understandable for the type of coming of age story that this anime is. We have a child literally risking her life in ascending the Abyss yet blatantly knowing all the life threatening dangers that lurk on her journey. Which is quite silly and very irredeem... wait I mean irresponsible, to begin with. 


Still the characters and the mystery that is the Abyss was captivating, you have the giant hole on an island like a dormant volcano which ended up attracting people all over the world to move here and settle down. Apparently there wasn't anything else to discover in the world anymore. The Abyss literally becomes a goldmine for the settlers in general and soon enough a booming enormous town is established with the Abyss as its core. Yes, as you can imagine it gets pretty interesting from there onwards.


For me the reason why this show got so much praise was to how unique is was, which to most avid anime consumer its damn refreshing. 2017 gave us plenty of the same trash we love, however Made in Abyss was quite different, to that which is clear as day evident in its amazing artstyle accompanying with very tone down fantasy style soundtracks unlike most fantasy genre anime we got his year. I don’t want to drop spoilers here but towards the last episodes the overall nature of this anime completely changing and i can honestly swear that tiny parts for soul were pulled out of me watching some of the most disturbing scenes I've seen in anime. 


All in all it is a completely worth watching anime. If you ever do find yourself in an situation of dropping it, then don’t. The ending was set on a high yet light note perfect for the build up to the second season which I feel is going to remind you that this is definitely not a light-hearted fun filled adventure anime for everyone.

Ten out of ten.

There's something truly enjoyable about shows that have an idea and really flesh it out as much as they can. 
Made in Abyss does a fantastic job of building upon its core concept by adding more and more information about its world for the viewers to consume. From start to finish it presents us with great ideas, backed up by wonderful artwork and fantastic musical choices. Every new layer in the depths of the abyss brings with it, fresh scenery, monsters, and obstacles. This constant influx of new things will keep you coming back for more and luckily for us, there's a season 2 onthe way.


The show is not entirely without fault however.


-The start may be a little slow for some people

-Certain decisions made by the main characters can be a little infuriating

-Sometimes the switch from dark & serious to cheerful & childish is a bit rough


I personally found the premise to be interesting enough to keep me around despite the slow start. In defense of the dumb decisions, the characters are children...curious, positive, cheerful, children. It is not out of the realm of possibilities for a 12 year old to make dumb decisions. The switches from serious to playful are in my opinion a little rushed from time to time. I would rather they let us sit in despair and agony for a bit longer before bringing back the youthful positivity our characters give us.


At the end of the day though, this show is a strong 9/10 for me. Beautiful artwork, good music, strong characters, and an engaging story, all set in a beautifully crafted world. Not much more you could ask for in a fantasy anime, I'll be eagerly awaiting the second season.

I am writing this review as I, so far, have only seen one other review that mentions the huge elephant in the room when it comes to MiA. This reviewer also did not like the show at all and rated it poorly.

The positives have been mentioned a few times already (skip this part if you have read other reviews);
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Story - Great init's simplicity. MiA has a very minimalistic plot and is rather about the concept of the longing for the unknown. The reason the minimalism works for MiA is because it makes everything it actually does stand out so much more. The sceneries and concepts, that would have just been part of the background and world building in another anime, becomes the main focal point and draw of the series in MiA. This is why the lack of a complex story makes it good. 8/10


Art - Decent pastel-colored cutesy loli art. 7/10


Sound - Quality varies but the good scores are really good! The bad ones are average. On the whole the OST suits the series perfectly and manages to build atmosphere and tension. I suspect it was heavily influence by Hans Zimmers work for Interstellar, but this is just a theory of mine. 8/10


Characters - Nothing special; two decent bland anime protagonists and a third slightly less cliche protagonist thrown in later in the show. It has some interesting side-characters with equally interesting design (and delightfully a good portion interesting female characters with other purposes than fanservice and tragic anime deaths). 6/10


Enjoyment - I thoroughly enjoyed this show for the creative setting and adventurous feel, and I did not find the irregular pacing annoying. There was just the right amount of curiosity and excitement for what is to come, mixed with a slow and deliberate building of the setting for me to stay entertained throughout these 13 episodes. 9/10
